title-group.article-title: Malignant Peripheral Nerve Sheath Tumor With Primitive Neuroepithelial Differentiation in an Adult
title-group.subtitle: A Case Report

author-notes.corresp: Arti Rameshrao Anvikar, Department of Pathology, Government Medical College, 56, Rama udyan, Phase-3, Pandharpur Road, Miraj 416410, Maharashtra, India Email: aartianvikar@gmail.com

abstract.p: Primitive neuroepithelial differentiation in malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors (MPNSTs) has been reported in children but is extremely rare in adults. The authors report the case of a 70-year-old woman who presented with swelling of the right leg of 1-month duration. Fine-needle aspiration cytology was suggestive of a benign peripheral nerve sheath tumor. Histopathological examination of the excised mass revealed a MPNST with spindle-cell areas and a few round-cell areas with rosettes. The spindle cells showed positive immunoreactivity for S-100 protein and vimentin and negativity for desmin, confirming their nerve sheath origin. The round cells were immunoreactive for synaptophysin and chromogranin, indicating primitive neuroepithelial differentiation. These cells did not stain for CD99, which is consistently expressed by the cells of primitive neuroectodermal tumors (PNETs) of bone and soft tissue but not by central nervous system (CNS) PNETs or medulloblastomas. In this case, the PNET-like focus resembled a CNS-PNET.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Malignant tumors arising from peripheral nerves or displaying differentiation along the lines of nerve sheath elements are collectively called malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors (MPNSTs). These tumors account for 5% to 10% of all soft-tissue sarcomas. Infrequently, MPNSTs contain areas of primitive neuroepithelial differentiation, especially in children and rarely in adults.1 We describe the histopathological and immunohistochemical findings of a MPNST with primitive neuroepithelial differentiation in an adult woman.

sec.title: Case History
sec.p: A 70-year-old lady presented with swelling over the right leg for 1 month. There was no history of trauma or pain at the site of swelling. Local examination revealed a well-circumscribed mass measuring 15 × 5 cm2. It was firm, nontender, and not fixed to the bone or skin. Systemic examination of the patient revealed no abnormality. Ultrasound examination of the swelling showed an ill-defined hypoechoic lesion measuring 13 × 8 × 8 cm3 situated over the upper leg anteriorly in the subcutaneous plane and involving the adjacent muscles. Fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) of the swelling was suggestive of benign peripheral nerve sheath tumor as there were no features of malignancy on FNAC. The patient did not have signs of neurofibromatosis type 1. The mass was excised. Grossly, it was an encapsulated fusiform tumor measuring 14 × 8 × 8 cm3. Cut sections had a fleshy white appearance with areas of hemorrhage and necrosis. Origin from the nerve could not be traced even after extensive sampling.

Histopathological examination revealed a tumor composed of spindle-shaped cells with elongated hyperchromatic nuclei and scanty cytoplasm arranged in densely cellular fascicles and whorls (Figures 1A and 1B). Many mitotic figures and foci of geographic necrosis were noted (Figures 1C and 1D). Neurofibroma-like foci with wavy, buckled nuclei and a light eosinophilic matrix were also seen. The tumor had a few areas that were entirely composed of monomorphic, small, round cells arranged in rosettes. The rosettes were of 2 types: Homer Wright rosettes with central solid cores of neurofibrillary material and Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes with central lumina (Figures 1E and 1F).

caption.p: Histological features with hematoxylin and eosin stain: A. cellular fascicles of spindle cells (100×). B. whorl (400×). C. hyperchromatic nuclei and mitoses (400×). D. geographic necrosis (100×). E. Homer Wright rosettes. F. Flexner Wintersteiner rosette (400×)

sec.p: Immunohistochemistry revealed diffuse positivity for S100 protein and vimentin with negativity for desmin in the spindle-cell areas. The round-cell areas were positive for synaptophysin and chromogranin and negative for CD99 (MIC-2 gene product).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The diagnosis of malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor is made when the tumor arises from a peripheral nerve or a preexisting peripheral nerve sheath tumor, but it can be difficult when the origin of the tumor cannot be traced. The diagnosis in such situations is made with the help of a constellation of histological features that include alternating dense and hypodense fascicles, asymmetrically tapered spindle cells with irregularly buckled nuclei, nuclear palisading, whorled structures that vaguely suggest tactoid differentiation, geographic necrosis, hyperplastic perivascular change, and presence of heterologous elements.1 About 50% to 90% of MPNSTs show positive immunoreactivity for S100 protein but do not express muscle-specific markers like desmin, muscle-specific actin, or smooth-muscle actin.1,2 In our case, there was no evidence of origin of the tumor from a nerve. Microscopic features in favor of a MPNST were presence of irregular buckled nuclei, geographic necrosis, and whorled structures. The presence of S-100 positivity and desmin negativity confirmed the diagnosis of MPNST. On FNAC, there was no evidence of malignancy, such as nuclear hyperchromasia, mitoses, or necrosis. This may be a result of sampling of neurofibroma-like areas, which led to the diagnosis of benign peripheral nerve sheath tumor.

Primitive neuroectodermal tumors (PNETs) are malignant tumors composed of uniform, small round cells with darkly staining round nuclei and indistinct cytoplasm arranged in sheets, lobules, and rosettes. PNET of bone and soft tissue is regarded as one end of the spectrum Ewing Sarcoma/PNET. The defining cytogenetic feature of these tumors is the presence of nonrandom translocation—most commonly t(11;22)(q24;q12)—leading to the fusion of the EWS gene on 22q12 with one of several members of ETS transcription factors. Also, 95% of these tumors express CD99 (MIC-2 gene product). Central nervous system (CNS) PNETs and medulloblastomas resemble these peripheral PNETs in terms of histology. However, the characteristic translocation as well as expression of CD99 is not found in CNS PNETs and medullolastomas.1,3

MPNSTs rarely contain areas of primitive neuroepithelial differentiation consisting of small round cells arranged in cords, nests, or rarely rosettes.1 PNETs can also arise from the peripheral nerve and may show a spindle cell pattern.1 Sometimes, the differentiation between MPNSTs and PNETs may be difficult, especially in children, when small round-cell areas predominate.4 However, such a distinction is critical because the treatment for the 2 tumors differs. PNETs are highly sensitive to chemotherapy, whereas MPNSTs are largely chemotherapy resistant.5 The ultimate differential diagnosis may only be possible with the help of immunohistochemistry or electron microscopy. PNET-like areas in MPNSTs may show positive immunoreactivity for one or more neuroepithelial markers, such as neuron-specific enolase, synaptophysin, chromogranin, and neural adhesion molecule. However, CD99 expression is negative in such cases, as it was in our case.6,7 Thus, the PNET-like focus in our case resembled the CNS-PNET rather than bone and soft-tissue PNET.

Meis et al4 found PNET-like foci in 15 out of 78 childhood cases of MPNSTs. All these cases also showed spindle-cell areas. Briscoe et al6 also mentioned the presence of a PNET-like component containing rosette-like structures with hypereosinophilic fibrillary cores in their case report of an orbital MPNST in an 11-year-old girl. The tumor also contained typical spindle-cell areas.

Shintaku et al7 reported a case of a 59-year-old man with a MPNST showing an admixture of small round cells resembling a PNET and a pleomorphic spindle-cell sarcomatous area. The small round-cell area showed abortive rosettes, primitive neural tube–like structures, and a few glandular structures. The tumor was assumed to be derived from primitive neuroectodermal cells in the peripheral nerve capable of bidirectional (neural and Schwann cell) differentiation.

Hruban et al8 in their study of 43 cases of MPNSTs reported similar findings in 4 adult cases, which included 1 case with a microscopic focus of Homer Wright rosettes, 2 cases with an exclusively small-cell neuroepithelial-like tumor, and 1 case with a predominantly small-cell tumor with a minor spindle cell component.

Abe et al9 and Kamishima et al10 have also described small round-cell areas in MPNSTs indicating neural differentiation. Abe et al also analyzed EWS chimeric transcripts by reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction. EWS chimeric mRNA was not detected in any of the cases. Such transcripts are present in more than 95% of cases of Ewing sarcoma/PNET.11,12

Primitive neurectodermal differentiation has also been reported in uterine tumors, ovarian malignant mixed mullerian tumor, and malignant gliomas.13-17 The presence of neuroectodermal differentiation in endometrioid as well as serous type of endometrial adenocarcinoma has been found to be a marker of aggressive behavior.13,14 Malignant gliomas with PNET-like components have the capacity to seed the CSF.17 The presence of PNET-like foci does not seem to alter the prognosis of MPNSTs in children.4 However, there are no data regarding the effect on prognosis in adults.

In conclusion, primitive neuroepithelial differentiation in MPNSTs should be distinguished from true PNETs because of the different treatment modalities for these 2 tumors. The impact of primitive neuroepithelial differentiation on the prognosis of MPNSTs in adults needs further evaluation.
